Headline: Aligning Strategy, People & Delivery for Growth | 25+ Years Driving Brand & Business Outcomes | Calm Clarity, Lasting Impact
Comment:
Entrepreneurs today have diverse options for funding and the risk appetite is higher compared to bygone years. The biggest gap I find is new startups missing in the sector that requires large investment or requires immense hardwork like say manufacturing. I might be wrong here. 

With Shark Tank giving the startups required visibility, we should start seeing more businesses from the tier 2, tier 3 areas coming into the limelight.

And the biggest segment where startups are required is: agriculture. Agriculture should be brought in the limelight, encourage youngsters to take up farming, cost reduction and increase in revenue per acre should give relief to farmer parents on the future.

Headline: 3x Founder | Building a customer-obsessed, anti-fintech company to solve for 120 mn+ Indian credit card users. Also, sharing stories via ‚ÄúPitch Please‚Äù
Comment:
Pfft‚Ä¶ India has always been an entrepreneurial society, going back centuries. Our consumption has been internal for most of the part, and that‚Äôs also natural given the population and consumption size. It‚Äôs etched into our fabric, our genetics (if I may go there), however, due to the neoliberal ideology and policies, we were pitted against each other, forced to ‚Äúbe in line‚Äù and ‚Äúfollow instructions‚Äù while our whole being cried for adventure. 

The new 2.0 version of businesses and entrepreneurs is just more aligned with the global economy than just domestic, which is why IPOs/M&A, etc., determine how much money will be poured into the markets.

Headline: Author | The Engineer-Analyst decoding the architecture of the future.
Comment: Shark Tank's role in shifting perception is huge. But I wonder if we're overlooking the support systems needed after the initial hype.

Headline: COO at Bombay Founders' Club
Comment: This is a fantastic perspective on how culture shapes entrepreneurship. Shark Tank has indeed been a catalyst in normalizing the startup journey for so many young Indians! It‚Äôs fascinating to see this evolution.

Headline: Growth Strategist & Business Builder | GTM, Product, Partnerships | Founder @ Conwert.in | Fintech, Proptech, F&B | Ex-EnKash, OYO, IWG | UCLA PGP
Comment:
All the platforms - from print media to TV shows - glorify entrepreneurship & start ups. Rightly so. This is how you ignite dreams in people. 
The flip side is that for every successful startup, there are perhaps 100 that failed.This is a side that does not get much attention or eyeballs. 
There's enough gospel online on how difficult it is to start something on your own. But no one talks about what one can do when a start-up fails. There's space there for guidance, coaching & more exposure. What say Avik Ashar?

Headline: Fundraising Consultant | Expert in Pitch Decks for Investors | Investor Outreach | Pre-seed to IPO | 1200+ Clients Served Across 20+ Countries & 10+ Time Zones | 800+ Decks | $25M-$30M Raised Through Us
Comment:
The "Dadi is proud" moment hit hard üòÑ
I've seen this shift firsthand. Founders now walk into family gatherings with their heads high instead of dodging questions about "when will you get a real job?"

Headline: milliGOLD | RSR Innovations
Comment:
I recall a shark tank video where an entrepreneur talks about how they place customer's money (saved for buying jewellery) in P2P platrms to give better returns to customers and all the judges (except one) highlight the financial risk,  legal, moral and ethical dangers of playing with mass market customer's money - not an educated financial investor - on the basis of fine print terms. The startup still gets a deal from the remaining one judge.

Now I hear news (post by Jayant Mundhra) about how OYO is issuing bonus shares where most retail shareholders may not do all the complex things required to get what they truly deserve (default option being a lopsided bonus ratio)

I wonder what kind of examples we are setting in the public imagination.

Headline: TMH | ISB | NISM i DeRisk Healthcare Investments for founders & funders, enabling profitable exits & scaled returns.
Comment: The counter to this is that Michael from Byculla with no business acumen thinks selling tea with 5 minutes is a gold mine of a qcom idea. No kidding. Being the eternal pessimist I think we need to also taper and tone it down to bring forth the reality of swear and blood and tears that go into being a founder AND an investor chasing an LP. we often end up glamourising hardwork. Most folks I meet horrify the crap out of me, very few sensible ones who understand fiduciary responsibility. An aerospace founder I met recently legit pays himself a 50 lakhs a year salary because why not while he struggles with runway every 6-8 months.

Headline: Helping social impact founders escape operational chaos and focus on what actually matters | Former Operator & Chief of Staff | Multiple successful turnarounds | One startup failure
Comment: for all the criticism the show gets, it has driven visibility to the fact that entrepreneurs can come from any walk of life and show people that there are others just like them, out there trying to make something worthwhile. Made entrepreneurship dinner table conversation. Priceless in our country.  Something no Govt program managed.
